snippet: Iraq’s dwindling Christians are leaving because they say they feel discouraged by unemployment and a creeping fear that the violence they had fled was catching up to them.
abstract: Iraq’s dwindling Christian population, driven from their homes by attacks and intimidation, are beginning to abandon the havens they had found in the north, discouraged by unemployment and fear that violence is catching up to them; quiet exodus is the latest chapter of a seemingly inexorable decline; recent assessments find that Iraq’s Christian population has fallen by more than half since 2003, and with the military’s departure, some Christians say they are losing a protector of last resort.
lead_paragraph: Iraq’s dwindling Christians are leaving because they say they feel discouraged by unemployment and a creeping fear that the violence they had fled was catching up to them.
